awd_titl_txt: Sterically Encumbered Guanidinates for the Kinetic Stabilization and Study of Terminal Iron Nitrides in Weak Ligand Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Skye Fortier of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) is investigating the synthesis and reactivity of complexes that contain iron bound to nitrogen (iron nitrides).  In both nature, and in industry, iron nitrides play a fleeting but critical role in capturing nitrogen from the air that we breathe and transferring it to important species (such as fertilizers for crop growth) ? a process known as nitrogen fixation. Despite the importance of iron nitrides in the global nitrogen fixation cycle (and in the marketplace), the study of molecules possessing individual iron nitride units has been hampered by the lack of model complexes.  This project is developing new molecular architectures to access, trap, and study reactive iron nitride compounds.  The goals are to shed light on the steps of the nitrogen fixation cycle and to use lessons learned to develop important, new nitrogen complexes using earth-abundant iron. Importantly, this chemistry utilizes iron which is a sustainable, non-toxic metal ? avoiding the need for costly and toxic precious metals.  This project provides research opportunities for early-career scientists, including students from historically underrepresented groups. UTEP is a minority serving institution with an 80% Hispanic student population. The training and development the students receive is critically important for preparing the next generation of domestic science and technology personnel capable of competing in the global marketplace. On top of this, in an effort to encourage an active role in their learning, a student-directed seminar involves students in the hosting and organization of departmental seminars twice per semester. This program includes an ?Ask Me Anything? interview session where the students can learn from the life and professional experiences of the guest speaker as a professional development exercise and to reinforce resiliency and fortitude as traits for success. 

This project involves the use of "super bulky" guanidinate ligands to kinetically stabilize reactive iron-nitride compounds and delves into the factors that affect iron nitride reactivity. Using redox chemistry and ligand modifications, structure-function relationships are examined as they pertain to the electronics and chemical behavior of the iron-nitride moiety. A goal is to modulate the reactivity of the iron-nitride unit through ligand field effects, effectively using the ligand as a "chemical remote control" to influence the nucleophilicity/electrophilicity of the nitride group.  A new professional development program at UTEP was initiated to better prepares the next generation of science and technology personnel.  Students have an active and dynamic role in their education through the student-directed seminar program.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the research activities of Prof. Skye Fortier and his research group at the University of Texas at El Paso. Specifically, the award was given for the investigation of using specially designed ligands to synthesize and study molecular compounds featuring iron-nitrogen triple bonds.  Iron-nitrogen triple bonds, in the form of iron nitrides, can be highly reactive groups, and the Fortier laboratory employed super bulky ligands to sterically protect these bonds.  The intellectual merit for this work was to better understand the formation, reactivity, and chemistry of iron nitrides in order to provide better insights into the fixation of nitrogen.  Nitrogen fixation is an important process for sustaining life. 

We successfully demonstrated that super bulky ligands, can give rise to isolable iron nitrides with sufficient lifetimes at room temperature. The super bulky ligand that we used, namely a guanidinate, is known as a ?weak-field ligand? as a result of its specific electron donating properties and effect on the orbitals at the metal center. These weak-field ligands have the tendency to destabilize metal-nitrogen multiple bonds, but through our use of a super bulky ligand, we employed steric control to provide kinetic stabilization of reactive metal-ligand moieties while favoring low-coordinate geometries to minimize anti-bonding contributions.  In the time that this project has been funded, we have unequivocally demonstrated the merits of this strategy through the successful synthesis, isolation, and characterization of such an iron-nitride complex. 

In addition to accessing a novel iron-nitride system, we extended our investigation to the study of cobalt.  By paring the steric encumbrance of the guanidinate ligand, we were able to generate unknown Co=N=Co compounds. The structural, electronic, and reactivity of these systems were thoroughly studied, showing that cobalt-nitrogen bonds are highly sensitive to the coordination environment of the metal center. Namely, we showed that strongly coordinating solvents such as pyridine could alter the electronics of the Co=N=Co moiety, leading to destabilization of the cobalt-nitride bonds to promote hydrogen atom abstraction chemistry. This information is important as it gives us more insight into the role that geometry and electronic structure plays in the reactivity and relative stability of these late metal nitride complexes.

The University of Texas at El Paso is a Hispanic Serving Institution with a greater than 80% Hispanic student population.  The broader impacts from this award included the creation of a Student Directed Seminar Series.  This series was meant to increase active learning participation of early-career scientist in their educational and professional development.  Specifically, through the Student Directed Seminar Series, both undergraduate and graduate student groups crafted, organized, and executed their own professional and research development seminar series with outside invited guests of their choosing.  This had the effect of impacting a broader student base beyond the laboratory walls.  In the five years of the award, this project sponsored 10 student organized events that were well attended and received by the undergraduate and graduate participants. An additional three guests were invited in Spring 2022 to participate in a series entitled "Pursuing a Non-Academic Career Path" to highlight alternative career paths in STEM outside of academia. These events were well attended and positively impacted traditionally underserved communities as the participants were largely represented by Hispanic students.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2022
Modified by: Skye Fortier

Image
